title: Discovery of microRNA gene mutations in ALS patient genomes

author: Chen Eitan, Weizmann Institute of Science

segmentation: Hi good morning, my name is honey Tan.
I'm a PhD student at the lab of Professor Ron Hornstein from the Whiteman Institute of Science.
And today I'm going to talk about the discovery of micro RNA genetic variations in human error stations.
But first I would like to thank the organizers for having me here and to thank the collaborators from Project mind, especially the Group of Young Welding.
Kolonnade Vandenberg, Amal Halabi, John Anderson, Bob Brown all contributed greatly to this project.
OK, so a LS is a very interesting disease.

Also because the key driving force in it is human genetic research and it's important to mention it because what we know today regarding the causative genes that leads to LS comes from human genetic studies.
Today we can explain almost 70% of the familiar cases in some of the sporadic cases by genetic mutations that have been identifying no jeans.
Like said, once in an off 72 many RNA binding proteins like fast TDP, 43 agent are in peas.
However, there are still about 30% of the familial cases and many of the sporadic cases that are still unknown and that we still can't explain.
In this figure you can see the percentage of LS that can be explained by genetic mutations.

One of the most interesting thing that you can see from this figure is that today after a very long gap with the pace of gene discoveries dramatically accelerated and this is mainly due to the advancement in genomic sequencing technology.
Recently, the main platform that was used was the exome sequencing technology that allowed identification of mutation in the protein coding gene.
Ohm's associated with the disease.
However, the downside of this method is that it overlooks its keeps.
Many of the non coding regions that aren't the genome.
So what we suggest is that perhaps these 30% that are still unknown might be explained by genetic variations that are located in the noncoding genome, such as the micro RNA's.
And why micro RNAs?

So my cronies are short single stranded RNA miracles which regulate gene expression post transcriptionally and in the past few years there already accumulating evidences for the involvement of micro RNA's in airless.

So first, as I mentioned, areas associated mutations have been identified in our name binding protein like fast and TDP 43 and thus it raises the hypothesis that dysregulation of our inactivity might be mechanistically involved in this pathogenesis.
Moreover, both of these genes were also specifically linked to Biogenesis of micro RNA's.

2nd a work from our lab has shown that loss of Micron activity provides an U in vivo model for modern aerial disease, and by that it established the importance of the micro RNAs for motor neuron survival.
And.
Lost, my cronies were also found to be globally downregulated in the motor neurons of human airless patients.

So here you can see micro RNA expression data from laser capture microdissected motor neurons and you can see that there is a global down regulation in the level of Micronet which is specific to the motor neurons and we can see that in the surrounding tissue which not including micro their motor neurons.
So all this finding lead us to think that perhaps genetic mutations which will lead to an aberrant Micron activity might also be associated with the disease.

And in order to understand which type of mutation will lead to such apparent Micron activity, I would like to go very briefly on the macro neighbor Genesis pathway, which will lead me to hover hypothesis.

Then they undergo 2 steps of processing initial processing inside the new close by that Russia.

Then the prima corner is being exported from the nucleus to the title plasm by exporting 5 together with ran GTP and I'll go back to expert in five towards the end of my talk.
So keep it in mind and in the cytoplasm the pre microrna is being further processed by the dice are complex resulting in the mature micro RNA.
The mature micrornas loaded together with a garnet and today together they create the risk complex which is the functional RNA induced silencing complex.

The micro Roni recognizes its target M RNA's base sequence complementarity of a short fragment of about 6 to 8 base pairs, which is called the state region, and this one is located inside the mature micro RNA and when it actually bound to its binding sites inside the three permit ERS of the M RNA is.
The regulation is actually formed.
So we can understand that there are three main factors that important for the function of the macrones, which are the micro names themselves.
The binding sites inside the through permit ERS, and of course the micro RNA Biogenesis cofactors.

So our hypothesis was that a LS associated genetic variations can be identified in genes that encode either the micro RNA genes directly, the micronic protein cofactors which are associated with the Biogenesis of the macrones, or in the three prime UTR's of jeans that are already known to be associated with the disease, like fast, for example, which can be regulated by the micro knees.

The non coding region when trying to identify new mutations that are associated with the disease in order to say that what we want to do is to find this type of mutation but in an unbiased manner meaning to screen all my corners that aren't the genome.
And all through family TRS of jeans that are known to be associated with airless.
In order to identify mutations in our regions of interest, we took advantage of two platform.
The initial platform was targeted capturing sequencing that we modified in a way that we allow us to capture and two sequence only.
Our regions of interest.
My coronary, three comparison cofactors.
We use this platform for deep sequencing of a large cohort of 400 LS samples and 100 controls and these were taken from the repository's of Bob Brown.

We then performed an independent study in collaboration with project mine, and especially with the Group of Young Welding from UMC Utrecht, for which we developed a new method which is called insilico capture.
In silico capture calls our specific regions of interest, which uses a very tiny fraction of three MB from their whole human genome sequencing data.
So this way we were able to analyze our fragments on their large cohort of more than 4000 Ala samples and almost 2000 controls.
Using this new platform, we then move to the data analysis.

We decided to perform the gene level aggregation analysis, which is still a relatively new genetic analysis in the field, which identified mutation into Bay for a, for example, as associated with their familiar form of wireless.

In this type of analysis, rather than looking on the individual variant, we're trying to see whether there are genes that tend to be mutated more often among the court of cases relative to the controls.
So the P value is actually calculated by aggregating all the very rare and very deleterious variants that are located in a specific gene window.

So for example, if this if we have this gene window and we have different patients with different mutations that are rare and deleterious, then each variant by itself won't be able to reach to statistical significance.
But then if we will look on the aggregated count, it might reach to statistical significance and it would tell us to genetic mutation in this gene might be associated with the disease.

In order to perform this analysis on our regions, that Recruiter and Macrones where to develop beautiful magical tools that will assign functional annotations for variants that are located in these regions.

Today I want to share with you an example for such micro Renee, like Mewtwo 18.

Nonetheless, in the capture and sequencing platform, we found one mutation in this macaroni in one case out of 340 relative to 9 in the controls.

In a total of 11 patients versus one in the controls.
